Train diffusion LLMs on your low cardinality high quality data, then use those to generate higher quality synthetic prose to train the transformers on.

arxiv.org/abs/2507.15857

reply_context.text: Actually for quality content main issue: there is so few and transformers has a high data inertia (and donâ€™t like abusive repetitions either: thatâ€™s actual model collapse). So we need to "replay" the data somewhat, hence distant writing.

posts.text: re: poetry and prose, I think a contributing factor is that most of the public content is trash like HS writing and fanfics, and the quality content is expensive and consequently not utilized and so not available to learn from.

reply_context.text:
I'd posit that synthetic data is primarily useful for:
* generating data for learning to solve inverse problems
  -> provide LLM a context to generate from, then try to predict context from generated output
* data augmentation as translation/morphism
  -> given text, rewrite as (style1, style2, ..)

posts.text: Maybe we need to be more like the white hat community and discuss abuse patterns more publicly/visibly. The issue is that many systemic vulnerabilities can't be simply "patched" like software vulnerabilities can, so any technical details necessarily also double as instruction manuals for bad actors.

reply_context.text: Speaking as someone who earned their data scientist chops working in this space, I often find myself in discussions online where I feel the need to explain things vaguely to mitigate the risk of instructing scammers how to better hide themselves.

posts.text: Speaking as someone who earned their data scientist chops working in this space, I often find myself in discussions online where I feel the need to explain things vaguely to mitigate the risk of instructing scammers how to better hide themselves.

reply_context.text: I think the "contours" of the design space aren't publicly visible to most people for OPSEC reasons. If you're a normie who doesn't have practical experience modeling fraud/abuse on a sensitive dataset at scale, I suspect there isn't a lot of public visibility on well established solutions.

posts.text: I think the "contours" of the design space aren't publicly visible to most people for OPSEC reasons. If you're a normie who doesn't have practical experience modeling fraud/abuse on a sensitive dataset at scale, I suspect there isn't a lot of public visibility on well established solutions.

reply_context.text: I don't mean this in a gatekeeping way, I mean it in a "Do not come into this field and assert authority with no humility when it's really a different problem set"

posts.text: The modern battleground is our system of values. We are rapidly losing the war, and I think a significant contributing factor is that our (American progressives/democrats) leaders continually refuse to fully acknowledge that this battleground (coordinated misinformation) even exists.

Diffusion training continues to extract value from the data beyond the irreducible loss achievable by the discrete causal objective. It renders post-training "polishing" unnecessary (insofar as that post-training is geared towards additional generalized performance improvement)

reply_context.text: It (seems to) resolve the need for RL to begin with. The reason post-training is needed is because the discretized (tokenized) causal prediction objective is bounded to a strictly higher irreducible loss. It converges faster than diffusion training, but as a consequence it leaves value on the table.
